comments.commentBody:
I’m independent. In NC we vote in either primary. Here is how I judged.
Which candidate is...
1. Intelligent and has thought through issues
2. Has a history of self control
3. Treats people with respect
4. Has some understanding of history and is will listen to advice at 4am in a crisis situation
HRC...is Intelligent and has thought through issues. She has little self-control and a history of abusing her Secret Service detail. One can be tough and respect others. Her behavior indicates her superiority to everyone else and it's obvious that she's not likely to listen to advice. She's pretty much a train wreck.
.
Sanders...There are no models for his policy plans. The US hasn't done well managing large federal entitlement programs. Bureaucracies are notoriously inefficient. I don't see how he gets his proposed programs through Congress, R or D without cutting military spending by half - not happening.
.
Trump...Where do you start. He didn’t pass any of my criteria.
.
Rubio…Out
.
Kasich…Super guy – no momentum
.
Cruz...Passes all four with the caveat that his flat tax at 10% probably needs to be 17 or 18%. The F.U.D (fear, uncertainty and doubt) raised by many comments in this thread just make no sense.
Cruz is not "scary" unless you think local government is scary.
Cruz isn't "dangerous". Congress was designed to be messy.
Cruz can't outlaw abortion. It's the law.
.
Lighten up. It’s only four years, then you can see if you want to hire your choice again.

Crews picked up most of Rubio’s voters. That’s not exactly a surprise. (Did anyone think they would switch from Rubio to Trump!?). And suddenly Crews looks more formidable. And if Kasich wasn’t in the race, Crews would also pick up most of Kasich’s voters. Without Kasich in the mix, Crews would probably have won the Wisc vote with nearly 60% of the vote. (Does anyone think Kasich voters would vote for Trump!?)

Crews’ biggest problem is Kasich, who hasn’t a scintilla of a chance of winning the nomination, either with delegates or with a brokered convention. Apparently he’s hanging in there because of (a) ego and (b) he thinks he might be able to use his position to nail down the VP spot on the Republican ticket.

He might succeed in that. But right now, Kasich is Trump’s best chance for winning the nomination.

Don't use Wisconsin as valid data point. The Wisconsin GOP is a hierarchical pseudo-military organization with the talk-radio media, politicians, and minions looking like the Russian Army marching through Red Square.
I cannot stand listening to the cruz whine. Climb back in your crypt and leave us alone.
No surprise here.  Wisconsin is the same state that elected smarmy Scott Walker.  I'm sure they love Cruz.

If Cruz gets the nomination, I will send him $50, a letter of congratulations, and an offer to volunteer for him--just in case he becomes president.  I'd rather be on his friend list than on his enemy list.

Terrifying. The only more terrifying thing will be that there will be a move to anoint Paul Ryan in the end, and he will win over Clinton or Sanders because for some reason everyone thinks he's some sort of moderate. He says he doesn't want it, but he said that last time too.
Seems to me that Wisconsin has gone from being a homeland of progressivism to being the Texas of the North.  No wonder Cruz did well in a state that elected and re-elected Scott Walker.

Cruz' victory in Wisconsin should be viewed as an outlier. Scott Walker had to win three gubernatorial elections in five years and the GOP machinery to accomplish that feat is still in place and its full force was put behind Cruz. I'm not sure that can be replicated elsewhere.

Cruz winning the nomination is very good thing.  Not only do you have a candidate who can not possibly win a general election, but you also get a third party campaign supporting Trump.  Democrats win the Presidency and control of both the Senate and the House.  Everybody wins -- including all those who think they lost.
I keep hoping I'll come across a Cartoon Editorial pic of Donald Trump with both feet sticking in his mouth and Ted Cruz offering him a shoe horn to help.
This is just what was expected to happen! Cruz will lose New York big and Trump will get back on track.

It's been the rage in prediction models to quantify the number of endorsements, but we have yet to see anti-endorsements. Perhaps Nate would like to best his counterpart Nate and create a chart. After all, we are dealing with two of the most hated candidates in recorded memory, and the dump Trump effort seems to have forgotten the joke, 'If Cruz was murdered on the floor of the Senate...'

Seriously, this campaign is not about who is liked more, it's who is hated less, and that can be quantified far better than it has to this point.

Cruz is delusional if he thinks he will be the nominee.  The Republican party wants to stop Trump, but they loathe Cruz nearly as much.  The end game is to get to a contested convention where they can draft Paul Ryan, who despite his protestations wants this so badly he can taste it.  And what a coup for him.   First getting drafted to be speaker and then the Republican nominee, which he will grudgingly agree to (secretly gleeful).  His certainly of infallibility will then know no bounds.    If that's not frightening, nothing is.

My hope is that this is a turning point towards some examination
of who this guy is. Pursuing its futile and unintelligent notion of
neutrality, the American press first gave Trump a pass -- never
really questioning his nonstop idiocy -- and now, regretful of its
lapse, it is going over him about everything. The result may be
end of Trump, but is certainly a pass for Cruz.

replies.commentBody: How can anyone support Ted?  I mean, seriously?  There is nothing authentic or sustentative w/ this guy.

I, too hope the RNC will "listen to the people" and put up either the loathed and loathsome Cruz or the truly despicable Trump for the Repub nomination. A hopefully sure-fire way to guarantee a presidential victory for the Democratic party and perhaps even move several of the Tea-Partiers up for re-election out of the House and Senate. "Listening to the people" will indeed signal the as-currently-constituted Republican Party's demise, fair payback for its out-of-touch-with-the American-mainstream race baiting, dog whistle, obstructionist politics of the last eight years. Then if only the working class base could be convinced to stop voting against its own self interest, our democracy would have half a of chance of meaningfully addressing, with rational policy decisions the myriad economic, energy and
climate challenges of the 21st century.

comments.commentBody: As a support of Ted Cruz, this is very exciting news that he is gaining momentum, however I do not see a contested Republican convention as being a benefit to the party. The republican establishment has set up this election itself. By appealing to conservative voters with campaign promises and then voting anything but conservative when in office they alienated voters. People are tired of the run around from government and party leaders not voting according to their wishes. This is how Donald Trump actually became a viable candidate with support, because he wasn't a part of the establishment that has let down so many voters. Ted Cruz has a proven record of voting the way he says he will vote and therefore is in the same boat. As much as I would prefer Cruz to Trump I believe not listening to the majority of the party constituents and putting another up for the presidency, the party will only further disgust people who already feel as though their wishes are not being properly represented by the people whom they voted into office. This is a critical point for the party. I just hope they listen to the people, not manipulate it to further their gain.

I would hazard a strong bet that a lot of the Cruz support in Wisconsin was simply a stop-Trump vote, by Republicans hoping for a brokered convention where someone other than Cruz is the ultimate nominee.  The same thing might happen in other states that wouldn't seem like friendly Cruz territory (even NY, where he slammed our "values").  Lots of people are probably holding their nose while voting for Cruz, as the lesser of two evils.  In the end, it doesn't really matter if Trump or Cruz is the nominee, because both are easily beatable.  But a brokered convention could produce someone else who might actually have a chance in a general election, so I'm kind of hoping Cruz prevails.

replies.commentBody: That's absurd.  "The typical Trump supporter doesn't know why they are supporting him?"  This divide and conquer thing is so old.  Is that why Wisconsin GOPers voted against Trump?  Because they didn't want to be seen as uneducated?  How shallow. Doesn't speak well for Wisconsin-ers.  Unless of course the whole point was to get their guy Ryan in via contestantion. They look pretty savvy if that was the plan.  For the record, I'm a Trump supporter, in the top 20% (whatever that means), have a post grad level education and know exactly why I'm supporting Trump.  But, what did the truth ever matter to anyone in politics.  Trump is learning the hard way and his face looks pained.  But I think he's nothing but resilient.  The only question he should answer is, "Is it worth it?"  Donald, it might not be.  The presidency is a popularity contest.  I don't think being the most popular has ever been your goal.  Don't start now.

While I agree with most of what you say, Trump's ego means he has to win, all the time.  But here's the rub, there's nothing wrong with that.  Trump speaks to a lot of angry people, including me, and I have a master's degree in business so please let's stop with the "uneducated" base of Trump support.  I still don't understand why he wants the job, short of a sincere desire to help this sagging country.  Someone has to tell me what's wrong with that.

comments.commentBody:
I would attribute Cruz's "hot-streak" mainly to the reduced amount of competition presented when Marco Rubio dropped out of the race. Both men ran election platforms which resembled one another; the main point being an anti-Trump campaign to keep Trump from receiving the Republican nomination. The voters who had intended on voting for Rubio are now left with a choice of who to back up. The choice, being between Kasich and Cruz, comes down to choosing the candidate who has the best chance at defeating Trump. Though Kasich is a viable candidate, he is too far behind in the polls to effectively defeat Trump overall. Therefore, the choice is evident that voters must choose Cruz.

It's also important to examine the population that did vote for Trump: the uneducated. A group of individuals who cannot discern the truth from Trumps lies, or understand when Trump has no idea what he is talking about. Rather they vote for him simply because they've heard his name before, because he is famous. The typical Trump supporter cannot give a single valid reason as to why Trump should become the President of the United States; most don't even know what issues the man stands for. However, as the election has progressed, some of these people have become aware of the issues and the policies, and removed themselves from that uneducated minority to join the populous under Cruz.

replies.commentBody: I'd prefer Trump to Cruz.  Cruz is a real lunatic.
Fool me us shame on you, fool me twice urr... you shouldn't fool me.

So I'll bite and suggest that either of them are a better alternative to Cruz, in fact the list of people better than Cruz could fit a sports stadium.  Sorry no religious extremist welcome as president of the United States, gk somewhere like iran if thats your cup of tyranny.

comments.commentBody: Unlike most, if not all of the commenters here, I am a Republican.  Although Ted Cruz is not my first choice, I have been hoping for an alternative to Trump.  I guess it will be Ted.  BTW: don't even bother suggesting Clinton or Bernie.  They make Trump look almost good.
My hope is that this win for Cruz was motivated by the Republican efforts to block Trump from acquiring  the delegates to secure the nomination before the convention.

Ted Cruz ably demonstrates that the grand tradition of the snake oil salesman is alive and well in today's bifurcated America where the .1% rule.

That Cruz could actually be considered as a "mainstream" Republican alternative to the self-important blowhard that is the Donald is beyond all comprehension. Neither one is capable of assuming the duties of a small town mayor, let alone those of President of the United States.

Several weeks ago, .1%ers were comforted by the notion that regardless of the disaster on the Republican side of the aisle, Hillary was totally in their pocket.

Now Sanders has tallied another win, Hillary's vulnerabilities are on full display. Her "truthiness" problem brings with it a kind of stale mouldiness that hovers around her like a bad aura. As weak a national candidate as either Cruz or Trump is, Clinton's negatives could turn the thing into a horse race.

Therein lies the Democratic Party's problem.

The situation may in fact turn on whether or not minority voters start to realize that the 73 year old white guy is actually speaking to them and their issues. If you can get traction with them, we may see Clinton's candidacy crumble. The truth is, while Hillary Clinton likes to go to black churches to speak, I can't for the life of me think of a single thing she's actually done for that demographic. You'd think that thought might have crossed their minds too.

Perhaps it will.

If it does, all political bets are off.

I'm not one to expend much time and effort analyzing the changing fortunes of Republican candidates, but I think moderates are defecting to Cruz b/c he represents the only viable alternative to Donald Drumpf.  Kasich's rise would only harm Cruz, not Drumpf.

Maybe Trump was a republican plant all along. Who else could make Cruz look "moderate," much less appealing?

Cruz is not better than Trump. He's just quieter.

replies.commentBody:
"States like Oregon will barely know there is an election while every household in Ohio will be saturated by Cruz."

Glad to be in Oregon.

comments.commentBody:
It has been evident for some time the Stop Trump campaign is a thinly-veiled cover for those Republicans willing to tolerate a Cruz candidacy but too embarrassed to support him openly. Even some of those who have come out for him do so allegedly on pragmatic grounds.....he has the best chance to stop Trump.....rather than because they want to share his platform and priorities.

But have no doubts because Stop Trump is Endorse Cruz. His eagerness last night to claim that mantle displays the eagerness with which he wants to be seen as the acceptable successor to Trump‘s narcissism. But it is important to appreciate the real Republican game has reversed. Through 2012 the power brokers and elites were willing to offer social conservatives lip service as long as they maintained control over economic and tax policy. As many key decisions came through the court system the elites could shrug and avoid responsibility. Cruz reverses this by offering that segment of the Republican Party seeking economic leverage free rein on tax policy, economics, and regulation in return for a free hand on the social agenda, including Supreme Court nominations. Cruz seeks to put together a coalition of opportunists and true believers that, buttressed by voter suppression, will prevail in November. Republican resources and manipulation will be focused on 7-10 key states that must be turned. States like Oregon will barely know there is an election while every household in Ohio will be saturated by Cruz

replies.commentBody: How come no one mentions that his wife, Heidi, works for Goldman-Sachs?

comments.commentBody: Someone who knows Ted Cruz better than most described him as a man whose opinions will not be changed even in the face of unassailable refuting evidence. I don't want someone like that in the White House. He doesn't belong there. He personifies hate, intolerance, and indescribably narrow views. He might know how to spell 'ethics' but far beyond him to put it into actual practice. He likes to represent himself as a Constitutional scholar, but every time he opens his mouth he proposes actions that trample all over that sacred document. It would be funny if it were not so frightening. Ted Cruz represents the second coming of Joseph McCarthy. An evil, smarmy, and sociopathically dangerous man.
